items.title: hashtable.c can't be compiled with msvc14 on windows
items.body:
As already discussed in #393 and worked around in #394 the c extension can't be compiled on windows because of invalid code for the msvc14 compiler in hashtable.c which is originated from https://gist.github.com/tonious/1377667.

They have newer versions over there, that may fix this and a lot of other bugs with the hashtable.

Or replace it with any other hashtable, or even use c++ std::unordered_map, or take a look at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1138742/looking-for-a-good-hash-table-implementation-in-c

```

items.body:
I think there is an issue in the API

```python
>>> from scss.types import Color
>>> from scss.extension.core import darken
>>> color = Color.from_hex('#ccc')

<Color #ccc>

items.title: zip_safe not declared
items.body:
While installing ``pyScss`` the following is spit out.

```
zip_safe flag not set; analyzing archive contents...
scss.config: module references __file__
scss.util: module references __file__
```

While it is no tragedy at all, that can be avoided by passing ``zip_safe = False`` to setup (called in function ``run_setup`` in ``setup.py``).

items.title: Complete control over search_path apparently not possible
items.body:
I want the compiler to look for SCSS files to be `@import`ed in only the directories
I supply with the `search_path` parameter (and in the order they are supplied, too).

However, if I read the code right, this only happens, when an absolute path is given for the file to be `@import`ed. For relative imports, the directory of the file containing the `@import` is tried first;
https://github.com/Kronuz/pyScss/blob/v1.3.5/scss/extension/core.py#L47 is where this happens.

Deleting lines 47-53 in that file gives me the behavior *I* want, but since that code is probably there for a reason that I don't quite understand, I'm guessing I'd be fucking over other people if I just handed in a pull request doing that.

For me, `rule.source_file.origin` being the last instead of the first directory to be searched would be a passable compromise - but since I don't really know what the reason for adding it is in the first place,
I don't feel like I can judge whether it's acceptable for people depending on the origin being added.

It'd be nice if someone told me why `rule.source_file.origin` has to be searched (first) or just implemented the compromise I described, if it is acceptable - or just gave me an alternative way
to accomplish what I'm trying to do.

items.title: currentColor not recognised
items.body:
Example - the following valid css 

```
background-image: linear-gradient(to top, transparent, currentColor);
```

becomes

```
background-image: linear-gradient(to top, transparent);
```

when parsed by pyscss, because `extension/compass._get_gradient_color_stops` is stripping out the currentColor argument.

Information about currentColor here: https://css-tricks.com/currentcolor/

items.body:
I'm a bit new at Sass, so I'm not sure exactly what all this is called, but I believe this is a discrepancy between normal Sass and pyScss:

Input:

``` css
$spacing-unit:     30px;
.footer { width: -webkit-calc(100% - (#{$spacing-unit} / 2)); }
```

CSS output from 

``` css
.footer {
  width: -webkit-calc(100% - (30px / 2));
}
```

items.title: statements in if function should not be evaluated unless targeted
items.body:
``` sass
color: if(false, <code block A>, <code block B>);
```

According to spec, `code block A` should not be evaluated, but it is.  It's causing issues because I have:

``` sass
if($propIndex, nth($strProps, $propIndex), 0);
```

and when `propIndex` is `null`, it throws an error.

My temporary work-around (for anyone else that might have this issue):

``` sass
if($propIndex, nth($strProps, $propIndex or 1), 0);
```

items.title: ValueError: Index cannot be zero when using str-slice
items.body:
Hi

I'm trying to compile an `.scss` file which imports [bourbon](https://github.com/thoughtbot/bourbon). We're using the `background` mixin of Bourbon but this seems to be causing an error. This mixin [internally uses the str-slice function](https://github.com/thoughtbot/bourbon/blob/master/app/assets/stylesheets/css3/_background.scss#L18) of Sass like so:

```
$url-str:       str-slice($background-str, 0, 3);
$gradient-type: str-slice($background-str, 0, 6);
```

However pyScss chokes on this:

```
Traceback:
  File "/Users/will/.virtualenvs/sass-test/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scss/calculator.py", line 141, in evaluate_expression

items.title: null variables are not stripped from output
append does not work correctly
Dots in filenames break imports
items.body:
Hello !
I noticed that dots in filename break the import system.
I tracked the issue down to these [lines](https://github.com/Kronuz/pyScss/blob/03ed722916bf8d376927bef7febb392fc7e218a4/scss/extension/core.py#L36-42).
The problem here is that when a dot is present in the name (coming from the import statement),
doing `search_exts = [path.suffix]` will consider anything after the dot an extension
and `basename = path.stem` will take everything before as the real filename.

A little example:
For this import: `@import "owl-carousel.animate"`, `search_exts` will be set to `["animate"]` and the basename to `"owl-carousel"`.
This will break the [path search](https://github.com/Kronuz/pyScss/blob/03ed722916bf8d376927bef7febb392fc7e218a4/scss/extension/core.py#L59-75) as it will search for `search_path/owl-carousel.animate` or `search_path/_owl-carousel.animate` where in reality it is `search_path/owl-carousel.animate.scss`.

I know I could just rename my files but it is working using libsass.

Thank you anyway for your efforts !

items.title: Wrong translation of e.g. top/25px
items.body:
Input:

```
..: url('..') left top/25px 25px no-repeat;
```

Output:

```
..: url('..') left "top/25px" 25px no-repeat;
```

Where `"top/25px"` is invalid CSS - it should be `top/25px`!

items.title: Variable Shorthand Property Bug
items.body:
When writing the following property in to a variable:
`url("images/icon.svg") left top/25px 25px no-repeat;`
it is being translated to
`url("images/icon.svg") left "top/25px" 25px no-repeat;`
which is invalid css, instead of
`url("images/icon.svg") left top/25px 25px no-repeat;`
which would be correct.

When doing the same thing without a variable, meaning assigning the shorthand property directly to, for example background, it is being translated to
`url("images/icon.svg") left top / 25px 25px no-repeat;`
which is, for all intents and purposes, correct.

items.title: Protocol-less imports broken
items.body:
We have CSS url imports which we intentionally leave off the http: or https: because it can be served in either http or https mode, depending on how the user hits our server. An example is:

@import url("//fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Roboto:400,400italic,300,900|Roboto+Condensed:300italic,300,400,700|Roboto+Slab:400,300,700")

We can't put "http:" or "https:" in here because the browser will complain about mixed secure/non-secure files. And we don't want pyScss trying to parse the imported CSS file. With this URL, we rely on the browser to use the appropriate protocol. See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4659345 for more info.

The latest version of pyScss inside scss/compiler.py explicitly checks for a leading "http://" or "https://" to get our desired behavior, and since our URL doesn't have this (nor a trailing ".css"), it continues onwards until pyScss reports a SassImportError. This is a regression for me.

            source = SourceFile.from_file(
                scss_file,
                relpath=filename or scss_file,

items.title: @extend doesn't work with &:after
pip3 install sometimes fails with UnicodeDecodeError
items.body:
I just tried to install pyscss into a docker container with pip install (on python 3.4, ubuntu trusty) and got the following error. Curiously, I don't get the same error on the host system, which leads me to suspect the behaviour has to do with some environment settings. I suspect the solution is to specify an `encoding=` when calling `open()` in the `read()` function in `setup.py`.

```
Downloading/unpacking pyscss
  Running setup.py (path:/tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/setup.py) egg_info for package pyscss
    /tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/scss/__init__.py:86: RuntimeWarning: Scanning acceleration disabled (_speedups not found)!
      RuntimeWarning
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 17, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/setup.py", line 144, in <module>
        try_building_extension()
      File "/tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/setup.py", line 123, in try_building_extension
        run_setup(True)
      File "/tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/setup.py", line 86, in run_setup
        long_description=read('README.rst'),
      File "/tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/setup.py", line 73, in read
        return open(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), fname)).read().strip()
      File "/usr/lib/python3.4/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
        return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 in position 1019: ordinal not in range(128)
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    /tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss/scss/__init__.py:86: RuntimeWarning: Scanning acceleration disabled (_speedups not found)!

  RuntimeWarning
<snip>
----------------------------------------
Cleaning up...
Command python setup.py egg_info failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip_build_root/pyscss
```
# Post script (and solution)

Yeah, from the docstring of `open` on python3, it uses [`locale.getpreferredencoding(False)`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html?highlight=open#open) to determine what encoding to use. On my host, it is `UTF8`, inside the docker container, it is `ANSI_X3.4-1968`. So it may be desirable to pin your `open(encoding=)` to `utf8`, if that's what is in the files you're reading.

For me, I worked around this in this specific case by putting `ENV LC_CTYPE C.UTF-8` in my `Dockerfile`, but pyscss is currently not portable.

items.title: join() function uses comma as separator when separator is not specified.
items.body: `join(10px, 10px)` in Ruby's scss outputs `10px 10px`, while `join(10px, 10px)` in pyScss outputs `10px,10px` - it seems the issue is in the `__parse_separator` function [here](https://github.com/Kronuz/pyScss/blob/master/scss/extension/core.py#L610).

items.title: Maps keys can't be Lists
items.body:
In Sass, `Both the keys and values in maps can be any SassScript object.`
That means Lists can be Maps' keys. But, in pyScss it failed.

``` scss
$susy-keywords: (
  container: auto,
  math: static fluid,
  output: isolate float,
  container-position: left center right,
  flow: ltr rtl,
  gutter-position: before after split inside inside-static,
  box-sizing: border-box content-box,
  span: full,
  edge: first alpha last omega full,
  spread: narrow wide wider,
  gutter-override: no-gutters no-gutter,
  role: nest,
  clear: break nobreak,
  debug image: show hide show-columns show-baseline,
  debug output: background overlay,
);
```

The scss code above which is part of `susy` will raise exception in pyScss.

``` python
SassSyntaxError: Syntax error after u'reak nobreak,\ndebug ': Found u'image: sho' but expected ":"
```

Function `PyString_AsString' implicitly converted to pointer at scss/src/_speedups.c:191

items.title: Much better handling of escaping
items.body:
Right now it's barely handled at all.  [CSS syntax](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-syntax-3/) allows escapes basically anywhere, in or out of strings.

I'm pretty sure we should evaluate all escapes when reading and then escape whatever needs escaping on write; preserving them would be a massive hassle and doesn't really gain the author anything.

This makes #192 even harder: `ur\6c()` is a perfectly valid way to spell `url()`, but right now the special URL parsing is done by checking for the literal sequence `url`.

items.title: kwarg parsing: "$list: ()" raises a syntax error
Some syntax errors produce no useful output
items.body:
The missing parenthesis in this expression doesn't result in any error, but just empty output, subtly breaking my CSS:

```
>>> compiler.compile("a {  margin-left: #{((($narrow_column_width * 1em - 1.5em) / 2)};")
''
```

While fixing the syntax error produces a decent error about an unknown variable:

```
>>> compiler.compile("a {  margin-left: #{((($narrow_column_width * 1em - 1.5em) / 2)) };")
Traceback (most recent call last):
SyntaxError: Undefined variable: '$narrow_column_width'.
```

items.title: Media Queries with Variables
items.body:
Hello there,

I'm trying to implement Twitter Bootstrap SASS version, but having issues. I'm running Python 2.7, and pyScss version 1.2.0.post3.

As a test, I've used iPython to compile a small piece of SASS. Here is what I ran:

In []: compiler.compile("$breakpoint: 768px;@media (max-width: $breakpoint) { .container{ width:900px; }}")
Out[]: '@media (max-width: $breakpoint){.container{width:900px}}\n'

Does pyScss not support variables within media queries?

Your help is much appreciated.

items.title: for loop bounds to/through
Wrong order using @import
items.body: Trying to compile bootstrap-sass results in wrong css. Pyscss seems to mix up the order of @import-statements in [bootstrap.scss](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap.scss). In my case it renders the _navbar.scss partial before the _navs.scss partial while ruby scss preserves the order of imports. This makes bootstrap unusable for me, as very basic components such as navigation links of the navigation bar are styled incorrectly.

Hi there! It's not possible (or I didn't find out how) to define a CSS selector for elements with a `':' or '\3A' (CSS)` in the class (for example `
test
`). ``` python from scss import Scss compiler = Scss() compiler.compile('div.width1\3A 4 {width: 25%;}') ``` This will return ``` css div\x03A.width1 4 { width: 25%; } ``` But imho it should return ``` css div.width1\3A 4 { width: 25%; } ``` Is there a possibility to escape the `\`?

items.title: Selector order is wrong when @extend is used.
CSS calc() gets confused by inconvertible units
items.body:
CSS' calc() allows mixing units that are not directly convertible so calc(100% - 10px) is valid value.

pyScss fails in such cases with a "can't reconcile unit" ValueError exception. I think the problem really is that it does  not distinguish calc() from normal sass number operations and hence does not simply leave it alone.

items.title: Can't run pyScss after upgrade
items.body:
Our systems guy upgraded our copy of PyScss to 1.2.0.post3 (evidently the old version was causing problems somehow), and when he did he broke our PyScss installation.

If I try to run it at the command line, like so:

```
python -mscss < static/scss/base_styles.scss 
```

I get:

```
Scanning acceleration disabled (_speedups not found)!
/homeme/work//bin/python: No module named scss.__main__; 'scss' is a package and cannot be directly executed
```

If I try running it through Python, I get an 

```
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'config'
```

on the line:

```
scss.config.LOAD_PATHS = os.path.join(settings.DJANGO_PROJECT_ROOT, "static/scss")
```

(And for the record, yes I know scss.config is deprecated, as the documentation says as much ... but the documentation fails to explain how else one can provide config info, and even the code example it gives relies on scss.config, so I'm stuck with config until there's an alternative.)

Finally, if I try to just pass the name of the file to be compiled (ripping out our old code entirely and using the code from the example):

```
_scss = scss.Scss(
        scss_opts={
            'compress': True,
            'debug_info': True,
        }
    )
    _scss.compile(scss_file="static/css/base_styles.css")
```

I get:

```
TypeError: wrapper() got an unexpected keyword argument 'scss_file'
```

The thing is, I don't care _how_ I do it at all, whether it involves config or the command line or whatever; I just need to be able to compile an SCSS file.

Please help!

items.body:
Otherwise they can't get at other variables in the current namespace, whereas a Sass function can.  Also can't get at compilation-local data or current options.

This will be a breaking change to `@register`, _but_ that can be averted if it's implemented at the same time as #132 with a new API (that also divines arguments and specifies types and so forth).

Might be related to #133, in that the current "compilation" is a useful thing to expose to a function as well.

items.title: Upgraded and Got Path Problems
items.body:
We recently tried to upgrade PyScss (to 1.1.5), but found that when we did we had a major path problem.  Essentially we're doing:

```
scss.LOAD_PATHS = os.path.join(settings.DJANGO_PROJECT_ROOT, "static/scss")
OUTPUT_PATH = os.path.join(settings.DJANGO_PROJECT_ROOT, "static/css/base_styles.css")
    compiler = scss.Scss(scss_vars={}, scss_opts=options)
    with open(OUTPUT_PATH, "w") as output:
        output.write(compiler.compile(self.src))
```

If I print out scss.LOAD_PATHS after setting it it does have the correct path to our SCSS files, and evidently it works well enough to find the base file (base_styles.scss), because we get errors about all the includes in it, like so:

File to import not found or unreadable: 'variables.scss' (<unknown>:0)
Load paths:
    /home/me/work/src/project
    /home/me/work/lib/python2.7/site-packages/scss/sass/frameworks

But getting errors for all those includes is obviously a problem, and nothing I do with the scss.LOAD_PATHS seems to influence the load paths that get printed out in the error message.

I'm at a loss for what I'm doing wrong, as it used to work just fine, and I seem to be pretty close to the instructions on the project page.  Any thoughts?

items.title: Variable in rem compiles to invalid css
items.body:
with:

```
VERSION      = 1.1.5
REVISION     = 20130215
BUILD_INFO   = pyScss v1.1.5 (20130215)
AUTHOR       = German M. Bravo (Kronuz)
AUTHOR_EMAIL = german.mb@gmail.com
URL          = http://github.com/Kronuz/pyScss
LICENSE      = MIT
PROJECT      = pyScss
```

and scss version 3.2.9, this happens:

``` python
>>> from scss import Scss
>>> css = Scss()
>>> css.compile("$var: 54rem; #some_id { width: $var }")
'#some_id{width:54 rem}'
```

(Notice the invalid space)
However, with scss command-line utility, the same thing compiles correctly:

``` bash
> scss --version
Sass 3.2.9 (Media Mark)
> echo "$var: 54rem; #some_id { width: $var }" > main.scss
> scss main.scss main.css --style compressed && cat main.css
#some_id{width:54rem;}
```
